lines.text: Oh, yeah. Oooh, ahhh, that's how it always starts. Then later there's running and um, screaming.
Rex just fed, so he won't be hunting for a while.
Just fed? I assume you're talking about Eddie? You might show a little more respect, the man saved our lives by giving his.
Then his troubles are over. My point is, predators don't hunt when they're not hungry.
No, only humans do.
Oh, you're breaking our hearts! Saddle up, let's get this moveable feast under way!
Mommy's very angry.
Don't worry, I'm not making the same mistakes again.
No, you're making all new ones.
[Eddie finds Ian, Sarah, and Nick trapped in a trailer hanging over a cliff]
What do you need?
Rope!
OK, rope! Anything else?
Yeah, three double cheeseburgers with everything!
No onions on mine!
And an apple turnover!
You know, I have made a career out of waiting for you.
You know, Sarah does have a pretty good p...
It's so important to your future that you not finish that sentence.
[after re-capturing the baby T-Rex in San Diego]
How do we find the adult?
Just follow the screams.

my fee? You can keep it. All I want in return for my services is the right to hunt one of the tyrannosaurs. A male, a buck only. How and when is my business. Now if you don't like either of those conditions, you're on your own. So go ahead, set up base camp right here, or in a swamp, or in the middle of a Rex nest for all I care. But I've been on too many safaris with rich dentists to listen to any more suicidal ideas, OK?
[after the adult T-Rex has escaped into San Diego and found a pool to drink out of]

[to asleep parents]
There's a dinosaur in our backyard.
[last lines]

It is absolutely imperative that we work with the Costa Rican Department of Biological Preserves to establish a set of rules for the preservation and isolation of that island. These creatures require our absence to survive, not our help. And if we could only step aside and trust in nature, life will find a way.
Did you find him?
Just the parts they didn't like.
It's fine if you wanna put your name on something but STOP putting it on other people's headstones.
Why don't people listen to me? I use plain and simple English, I don't have any accent that I'm aware of...
Oh, shut up.

[about the baby T-Rex]
He's too drugged.
He's never gonna know we have it if the thing doesn't make some kind of sound.
Come on. Wake up. Come on. Come on. Wake up.
[baby T-rex growls. Adult T-Rex sniffs the air then roars in their direction]
He knows.
[searching the island for Sarah]
Sarah! Sarah!
Sarah Harding!
How many Sarahs you think are on this island? Sarah!
[to Ludlow as the T-Rex terrorizes San Diego]
Now you're John Hammond.
This is a game trail, Mr. Ludlow. Carnivors hunt on game trails. Do you want to set up base camp or a buffet?
[about the Compsognathus]
It gives me the creeps, like it's not scared.
There haven't been any visitors on this island. There's no reason for it to fear man.
[Dieter touches a cattle prod to the dinosaur's head, causing it to flee]
Now it does.
I need something pliable... Spit.
[Holds out her hand]
[Spits saliva into her palm]

[Disgusted]
Your *gum*!

What are you talking about? Five years of work and a hundred miles of electrified fence couldn't prepare the other island. And you think that, what? A couple dozen Marlboro men were going to make a difference here?
I love you. I just don't... need you right now.
I'll tell you what you NEED, a good anti-psychotic!
I'll be back in five or six days.
No, you'll be back in five or six PIECES!

[to Hammond]
So you went from capitalist to naturalist in just 4 years. That's something.
Don't go into the long grass!

[to Ian]
I've worked around predators since I was 20 years old. Lions, jackals, hyenas... you.
[When Sara's camera runs out of film and the baby dinosaur roars]
Oh, they get very angry when you run out of film.
Hey, when the adult sees us once again with his baby, uh, isn't he gonna be like, "You"? You know, there may be some, uh, angry recognition.
Who knows? He may be just happy to see us.
Don't light that! Dinosaurs pick up scents from miles away.We're here to observe and document, not interact.
Which is a scientific impossibility.Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. What you study, you change.

I'll risk it. I'm sick of scratching around in rock and bone... making assumptions about the nurturing habits of animals... that have been dead for 65 million years.Then you fill my head with stories. Of course I came down here.
Stories of mutilation and death. Were you paying attention?
Please! Don't treat me like a grad student.I've worked around predators since I was 20.Lions, jackals, hyenas, you.
You seem like you have a shred of common sense, what the hell are you doing here?
Somewhere on this island is the greatest predator there ever lived. The second greatest predator must take him down.
[grins]

[referring to Roland's gun]
You gonna use that?
If he doesn't surrender, yes.

[chuckles]
The animal exists on the planet for the first time in tens of millions of years and the only way you can express yourself is to kill it.

Remember that chap about twenty years ago? I forget his name. Climbed Everest without any oxygen, came down nearly dead. When they asked him, they said why did you go up there to die? He said I didn't, I went up there to live.
When you try to sound like Hammond, it comes off as a hustle. I mean, it's not your fault. They say talent skips a generation. So, I'm sure your kids will be sharp as tacks.
Hammond's reach exceeded his grasp. Mine does not.
Taking dinosaurs off this island is the worst idea in the long, sad history of bad ideas. And I'm gonna be there when you learn that.
She doesn't even have Sega. She's such a troglodyte.
Cruel, but good word use.

[referring to Ian and Kelly]
Do you see any family resemblance?
I'll be right back. I give you my word.

[pounds her fists on the railing]
But you *never* keep your word!
What's everybody looking at?
[spots the T-Rex transfer ship speeding towards the harbor]
We should've stayed in the damn car.
[why Sarah didn't tell Ian about going to the island]
Because I knew you would have stopped me from coming.
I would have tied you to the bed.
I figured out how the dinosaurs survived without lysine.
I don't care!
[after taking the baby T-Rex and putting it in the car]
Hey! What the hell do you think you're doing?
I'm taking the kid. If you really want to stop us, shoot us.
Eddie, is there any reason to think that the radio in the trailer might work?
If you feel at all qualified, try turning the switch to "on."

[discussing the building of a Jurrasic Park in San Diego]
the city of San Diego is already famous for its animal attractions... The San Diego zoo... Sea World... The San Diego Chargers.
[During the dinosaur chase, the dinosaur hunters close in on a Parasaurolophus]

[over radio]
Dieter, get in the outrigger. You're closing in on a parasauro...

[over radio]
Say that again, Roland. A what?

[over radio]
The one with the big red horn! The pompadour! *Elvis!*

[to Kelly]
Hey, you want some good parental advice? Don't listen to me.

[to Dieter, just after the base camp attack]
That's the last time I leave you in charge.
[about the high hide]
It keeps you out of harm's way, away from the animals.
Actually, it would put them at very convenient biting height.
Dad, are you mad?
No, I'm not mad - I'm furious!
[Looks around the messy trailer]
What is this? This looks like your room.
You know, it's very easy to criticize someone who generates an idea, someone who assumes all the risk. Someone who puts.
[about the poison on the darts in their guns]
The most powerful neurotoxin in the world. It works faster than the nerve conduction velocity, which means the animal's down before it actually feels the - P! - prick of the dart.
Is there an antidote?
What, like if you shot yourself in the foot? Don't do that, you would be dead before you even knew you had an accident.

[referring to the T-Rexes]
This isn't hunting, Ian, it's searching. They're looking for their infant.
Let's not disappoint them.
[to his daughter, Kelly]
The queen, the goddess, my inspiration.
What's your background? Wildlife photography?
Yeah. Wildlife, combat... you name it. When I was with Nightline, I was in Rwanda, Chechnya, all over Bosnia. Do some volunteer work for Greenpeace once in a while.
Greenpeace? What drew you there?
Women. 80 percent female, Greenpeace.
That's noble.
Yeah well, noble was last year. This year I'm getting paid. Hammond's check cleared, or I wouldn't be going on this wild goose chase...
Uh, where your going is the only place in the world where the geese chase *you*!
Hang on, this is gonna be bad.
You sent my girlfriend to this island alone?
Sent is hardly the word. She couldn't be restrained.
Violence and technology... not good bedfellows!
OK, so there is another island of dinosaurs, no fences this time and you wanna send people in, very few people, on the ground? Right?
You looking for a problem?
And I found you, didn't I?
The school cut you from the team?
[while luring the T-rex to follow them to the docks]
Ian, slow down.
[Ian looks behind him and sees the T-rex coming]
Uh... I don't think so.
Careful. This suit cost more than your education.

[to Sarah as she's trying to fix the baby T-Rex's leg]
Whenever you're ready, he's fighting here, Dr. Quinn.
[Roland is sitting in a bar in Kenya. Ajay walks in behind him, and Roland turns around]
Ajay!

[laughing]
How did you know?
[they hug]
That cheap aftershave I send you every Christmas, you actually wear it. I'm touched. Sit down. What on earth brings you to Mombassa?
[they sit]
You, my friend. I got a call from a man who's going to Costa Rica, or thereabouts. And if I'm to be believed, its a most well-funded expedition.
Well, I'm a very well-funded old son of a bitch. You go.
What, alone? But we always had such great success together, you and I.
A little too great, don't you think?
What do you mean?
A true hunter doesn't mind if the animal wins. There weren't enough escapes from you and me, Ajay. We were like a firing squad, don't you think?
I have reason to believe you would find this expedition's quarry most challenging.
Then it's probably illegal. These days it's a worse crime to shoot a tiger than to shoot your own parents...
[sees some American tourists causing trouble with a waitress]
Tigers have advocates...
[downs his drink]
Excuse me, would you?
Roland, there's a job for you in San Diego if you want it.
No thank you. I believe I've spent enough time in the company of death.
Where's the crew?
All over the place.
Boy she's mad at you.
I feel sorry for that guy Enrique.
Ow Ow Ow! Don't do that! You gotta baby it a little bit.
I'll love it when it works.
It'll work when you love it. Let me do it...
[Chasing dinosaurs on the game trail]
You're coming up on a...
[flips through his dinosaur guide]
A Pachy... a pachy... oh, hell. Uh, the fathead with the bald spot. Friar Tuck!
You okay, Mr. Ludlow?
I don't know, how do I look?
Don't light that! Dinosaurs pick up scents from miles away. We're here to observe and document, not interact.
Which is a scientific impossibility.Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. What you study, you change.

I'll risk it. I'm sick of scratching around in rock and bone... making assumptions about the nurturing habits of animals... that have been dead for 65 million years. Then you fill my head with stories. Of course I came down here.
Stories of mutilation and death. Were you paying attention?
Please! Don't treat me like a grad student. I've worked around predators since I was 20. Lions, jackals, hyenas, you.

[to Ian]
You like to have kids but you don't want to be with them, do you?
[On being invited on the Costa Rica expedition]
Ajay, go down to my ranch, take a look around the trophy room, and then tell me what kind of quarry is on this hunt that would interest me?

[about the stegosauruses]
They're just protecting their baby.

[about Sarah]
So am I.
Wait, what's that, veloc-o-?
Velociraptor. Carnivore, pack hunter. About two meters tall, long snout, binocular vision, strong, dextrous forearms, and killing claws on both feet.
And the rex may continue to track us, too, if they perceive a threat to themselves or to their infant.
No, no, you're wrong there, Dr. Harding. We'll lose them once we leave their territory.
No, don't bet on it. Tyrannosaurs got the largest proportional olfactory cavity of any creature in the fossil record with the exception of one.
Right, right, the uh, turkey vulture. Could scent up to ten miles.
Right, this is all very thrilling, but I say we should push on to the village, hmm?

[while a T-Rex is right outside the mouth of the cave they're hiding in, Burke notices a snake crawling into his shirt]
Oh, my God! AH! A snake! Help me!
[first lines]
I love you. Thank you so much. Fabulous!
[a glass of white wine is poured]
Thank you, Geoffrey.
You're welcome.
We'll also take a bottle of red, as well. Thank you.
Certainly.
Right. Now... Oh!

[handed a glass of wine]
Thank you, Bernard.
You're welcome.

[takes sandwich from serving tray]
Thank you.
Wonderful. Beautiful day.
[to Cathy]
Sweetie, where are you going?
Eating my sandwich.
